Samsung Galaxy Gear→

The Verge:

Samsung promises "about a day" of endurance from the Gear, but by the end of our briefing with the company, the cameras on most of its demo units were refusing to turn on due to the watches running low on power.

$300 for this?

September 04, 2013
Nintendo

John Gruber:

The world has changed in the last five years, and hundreds of millions of people now carry powerful, well-made, touchscreen computers with them everywhere they go.

John Siracusa:

As long as there continues to be a market for devices that are primarily designed to play games, then it’s possible for Nintendo to live to fight another day.

Is there a big enough market for dedicated gaming devices to sustain Nintendo?

September 03, 2013
Dark Patterns→

The Verge:

A dark pattern is a user interface carefully crafted to trick users into doing things they might not otherwise do, such as buying insurance with their purchase or signing up for recurring bills.

Some of this is bad design, some of it is intentional.

August 30, 2013
Why do Scalpers Exist?→

Priceonomics:

When there is excess demand for a new car or phone, some people might sell theirs at a markup on eBay, but there’s nobody across the street from the dealership or Best Buy offering it right away for double the sticker price...

Yet concerts and sporting events consistently price their tickets low enough that street scalpers risk jail time to hawk marked-up tickets, and StubHub makes hundreds of millions a year in revenue.

Sci-Fi Suburbia→

The Verge:

Robots and hovercrafts are commonplace, and decaying science facilities sprout from the harsh Scandinavian landscape.

Incredible paintings by Swedish artist Simon Stålenhag.
